Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2010 01:29AM septembersong wrote: Vmarie, I'm so sorry to hear of this, but you aren't alone. Take a deep breath. Remember that you are going into this well and strong, and that stregth will help you to deal with what lies ahead.  My suggestion is to listen carefully to what the doctors tell you (and please bring your husband/partner/best friend who is comfortable dealing with doctors), and, as much as you can, review, research, and think about what they suggest before making any decisions. My only regret about my treatment was that I had my lumpectomy done by a local sugeon instead of going to a breast-cancer surgeon at Dana-Farber, where I was subsequently treated. But even that was fine--just something I'd have done differently in restrospect. In any case, for now, please do whatever takes your mind off these worries and take good care of yourself. Play with your boys, cook or bake, sit with your sister or a friend, go to dinner with your husband, ride your motorcycle. There's a wide circle of women here who will reach out with practical advice and loving support when you're ready to tap into it. Sending healing thoughts to you and your family.
Posts.Title: mental state Iamstronger Marie821

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2014 06:41PM septembersong wrote: Slappy-Squirrel,  My understanding of the difference between screening and diagnostic mammograms is that a radiologist analyzes the results of a diagnostic mammogram while you wait and delivers the report right away. In a screening mammogram, the results are returned within a matter of days. Once you've been diagnosed with and treated for breast cancer, diagnostic mammograms are pretty much the standard--or they are at the center where I'm treated. I know I'm more comfortable getting the results the same day I see my oncologist or nurse practitioner.  On the other hand, my insurance doesn't cover the diagnostic test completely, so I'm now paying a few hundred dollars for what used to be free. Sigh.  And I'd love to hear the story of your name.   Ann

Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2013 04:50PM septembersong wrote: Spoomsister, I've been following your story from the beginning too. I can't add much to what's been said here, and I had a different diagnosis/treatment plan. (I will say it's worth trying to hang on to your hair, if you have the resources and energy. Otherwise, you'll get a whole new look when it grows back.) But I do know attitude (yours and those around you) makes a big difference in getting through treatment and adjusting to life afterward. You are tough and strong and have a sense of humor, which believe me is huge in all this. These are hard and scary days, but, as Marie said, you are so not alone. Thinking of you and that wonderful husband of yours and sending healthy thoughts.

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2014 03:41PM septembersong wrote: Spoom,  My son works with someone whose wife had a prophylactic double mastectomy--she's a young woman with young kids, and had a very strong likelihood of developing BC. They had a party to mark the occasion. On the surface it doesn't seem like something to celebrate, but maybe it is--if the mastectomy will save your life and keep you safe. So you can be around to raise those kids, enjoy life with your husband, and plan for a long and happy life.   Keeping you in my thoughts. I hope the surgery goes well and that you have a short and uneventful recovery! Ann
Posts.Title: Found breast tethering while fixing my hair. :o( Spoomsister Roxybabes

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2009 06:57PM septembersong wrote: Ang, it's no wonder you're so anxious--I was a mess before starting chemo, and I'd never heard of anyone dying from an infection during treatment. I totally agree with Titan that you should tell your nurse right away about how your friend died, and that it's making you extremely anxious. I had 12 weekly infusions of Taxol and Herceptin, and the nurses were really terrific--not just mine, who was great, but I saw many, many nurses giving extra attention and spending additional time with patients who were anxious or uncomfortable.  Chemo DOES save lives, and it will greatly improve your chances of living to raise those girls and enjoy them as they grow. This must be just dreadful for you. Please know that we are thinking of you and will be here to answer questions and cheer you on till this experience is over and done.

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2012 04:46PM septembersong wrote: First of all, so happy to hear your good news. That is just the best.  Second of all, no, not surprised that you cried all day. With what you've been through physically and emotionally, it's no surprise that all that dread and anxiety resolved in a day-long cry. Just too much going on. And really, too much to take in. Third of all, can you go to your employer and tell them that you've had unexpected good news about your health, and that your doctor sees no reason for you to stop working? I admit I don't know the lead-up to your resignation, but if you're on good terms with your employer, why not simply share the situation with them? I apologize if I've missed something critical on this point.   Very happy to read your good news. It's wonderful, and I wish you many peaceful, happy moments as it sinks in.

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2010 06:02PM septembersong wrote: Pat, I can only tell you that a colonoscopy is NOT a difficult procedure for anyone who's been through diagnosis and treatment for breast cancer. The preparation is not fun, but the procedure itself goes by very quickly. Once you get to be 50 all your friends will be having this lovely experience and laughing about it afterward. So please put your mind at rest about this! At my hospital they actually send you  pictures of your colon--as a mememto? for your files? In any case, sending you good thoughts and best wishes for peace of mind and body.

Posts.Title: So far so good...:-) kirismum shorfi

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2010 01:44PM septembersong wrote: Yes about never wanting to see that bag once all this is done. A very dear friend took me shopping for a tote bag before i started chemo, telling me that since she and her husband couldn't come to treatment sessions with me, they wanted me to have something that would remind me that they were thinking of me while they couldn't be there. I was profoundly touched. When I started chemo, and saw that nearly every other woman there carried a Vera Bradley bag, I felt that i had really passed over to the other side. I still have it, of course, and it's lovely and functional, but I wince every time I look at it. It stays in the closet. So get her whatever she wants, secure in the knowledge that you'll be carrying it yourself one day.

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2012 12:20PM septembersong wrote: fredntan, Congratulations on getting through treatment! It can be quite an ordeal. You HAVE come far. I'm nearly four years out from diagnosis. What I can say, at this point, is that recovery time seems to vary greatly, and has a lot to do with your treatment and your reaction to the drugs you were given and the regimen your doctor prescribed. But good nutrition, regular exercise, and support from friends and family make a huge difference. Seeing a naturopathic dr. seems like a great idea. At some point you'll realize that you're not thinking about your health or this frightening disease quite as often as you were. Keep focusing on regaining your good health. Sending best wishes for a smooth and speedy recovery!
